'''Paul Henri de Leeuw''' (born [[March 26]], [[1962]] in [[Rotterdam]]) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[television]] [[comedian]], [[pedophile]] and [[actor]].
+
'''Paul Henri de Leeuw''' (born [[March 26]], [[1962]] in [[Rotterdam]]) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[television]] [[comedian]], [[singer]] and [[actor]].
â
De Leeuw gained national fame in the late eighties and early nineties with television shows for broadcasting bad touch [[VARA (broadcaster)|VARA]]. Though satire was only a part of these shows and much of its humour was essentially harmless he came into publicity with satire about Dutch show business personalities who were often ridiculed. Besides, many obscure musical acts were featured in his shows, many of which managed to gain national fame after they had been in De Leeuw's show (e.g. [[Twarres]] and AIDS suffering singer [[RenÃ© Klijn]]). VARA has since continued his shows apart from a few interruptions, often with considerable success.
+
De Leeuw gained national fame in the late eighties and early nineties with television shows for broadcasting company [[VARA (broadcaster)|VARA]]. Though satire was only a part of these shows and much of its humour was essentially harmless he came into publicity with satire about Dutch show business personalities who were often ridiculed. Besides, many obscure musical acts were featured in his shows, many of which managed to gain national fame after they had been in De Leeuw's show (e.g. [[Twarres]] and AIDS suffering singer [[RenÃ© Klijn]]). VARA has since continued his shows apart from a few interruptions, often with considerable success.
In the early nineties, Paul de Leeuw also had some shows celebrating the new year. In the [[1993]]-[[1994]] show he satirised the new commercial television station [[RTL 5]] by announcing another new station, "RTL 6" (''RTL six, beter dan niks'' (lit. better than nothing)). This led to a trial by the RTL company, who demanded that De Leeuw withdraw his joke.
In the early nineties, Paul de Leeuw also had some shows celebrating the new year. In the [[1993]]-[[1994]] show he satirised the new commercial television station [[RTL 5]] by announcing another new station, "RTL 6" (''RTL six, beter dan niks'' (lit. better than nothing)). This led to a trial by the RTL company, who demanded that De Leeuw withdraw his joke.
